rsbNotes.title: Jer 46–51
rsbNotes.text: 46:1–51:64 This section of Jeremiah comprises a series of judgment oracles against the surrounding nations.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:23–27
rsbNotes.text: 49:23–27 A prophecy against Syria, or Aram. Syria impinged chiefly on the northern kingdom of Israel in the Assyrian period (1 Kin. 20; Amos 1:3–5). The three states named here had fallen to Assyria in the eighth century b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:23
rsbNotes.text: 49:23 Damascus . . . Hamath . . . Arpad. These are major Aramean city-states.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:28–33
rsbNotes.text: 49:28–33 A prophecy against Arabian kingdoms. Arab nomadic tribes posed a periodic threat to settled communities (Judg. 6:1–6). The present prophecy may have been occasioned by an Arab uprising against Nebuchadnezzar in 598 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:28
rsbNotes.text:
49:28 Kedar. An Arab tribe well-known in the Old Testament period (Gen. 25:13; Is. 21:16, 17; 42:11).

Hazor. Also in the Arabian desert, and not the well-known Hazor in northern Israel; this name may have designated a number of Arab settlements including Teman, Buz, and Dedan (25:23, 24).

people of the east. Another designation for Arab tribal peoples (Judg. 6:3; 7:12; Job 1:3).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:31
rsbNotes.text: 49:31 dwells securely . . . no gates or bars. These nomadic peoples typically lived in unwalled towns, not depending on fortified cities. See the description of Laish in Judg. 18:7. They were no match for a well-armed invader.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:34–39
rsbNotes.text: 49:34–39 A prophecy against Elam, an important power to the east of Babylon, subjugated by Assyria, but resurgent in the Babylonian period. The prophecy possibly relates to a Babylonian containment campaign against Elam in 595 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50–51
rsbNotes.text: 50:1–51:64 The prophecy against Babylon (cf. Is. 13:1–14:23; 21:1–9) is the climax of the book. The previous prophecies have served Jeremiah’s purpose of showing that Babylon would prevail over “all the nations” (27:7) for a period. Babylon has appeared up to this point as the instrument of God’s wrath. Finally, however (as in 25:17–26), “the word of the Lord” is uttered against Babylon itself, to show that its own time of judgment must come (25:11, 12). The Hebrew text of Jeremiah has placed the prophecy (actually delivered in 593 b.c.; see 51:59 note) at this point in the book so that the judgment on Babylon may occupy the climactic position. The relative length of the prophecy also shows how important Babylon is in the theology of the book.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:2
rsbNotes.text: 50:2 Bel . . . Merodach. Merodach or “Marduk” was the creator and chief deity in Babylonian myth. He was also called Bel, an early form of the word “Baal” (“lord”). See also Is. 46:1.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:3
rsbNotes.text: 50:3 out of the north a nation. See 1:14; 6:1. The tables are now turned on Babylon. The nation in question is not specified, but see 51:27, 28.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:5
rsbNotes.text: 50:5 everlasting covenant. See 31:31–34; 32:40; 33:20, 21.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:9
rsbNotes.text: 50:9 I am stirring up . . . against Babylon . . . from the north country. Cyrus is mentioned in Is. 41:25; 45:1. Members of the alliance are named in 51:27, 28.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:12
rsbNotes.text:
50:12 your mother. The city of Babylon is personified.

last of the nations. She had seemed invincible (Is. 14:12–17).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:19
rsbNotes.text: 50:19 Carmel . . . Bashan . . . hills of Ephraim and in Gilead. These are the most fertile parts of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:21
rsbNotes.text: 50:21 Merathaim . . . Pekod. These words are puns on Babylonian place-names (Marratu, Puqudu). The Hebrew words mean “double rebellion” and “punishment.”

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:24
rsbNotes.text: 50:24 taken . . . you did not know it. The Persian defeat of Babylon was unexpected.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:27
rsbNotes.text: 50:27 bulls. That is, Babylon’s army (46:15 note).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:28
rsbNotes.text:
50:28 They flee. Jewish escapees from Babylon returned to Jerusalem.

vengeance for his temple. The burning of the temple (52:13) was the definitive destruction of Jerusalem. The Lord ties His vengeance on Babylon specifically to that.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:29
rsbNotes.text: 50:29 the Holy One of Israel. This name for God is frequent in Isaiah.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50:34
rsbNotes.text: 50:34 Redeemer. See note 31:11.
